template_details.issue_description: When you compile a Solidity codebase, the compiler generates compilation artifacts, which include information about the contracts and their bytecode. If there are two contracts with the same name, the compiler will encounter a naming conflict and will not be able to generate compilation artifacts for both contracts.
template_details.issue_remediation: To resolve this issue, you need to ensure that all contracts within your codebase have unique names. Renaming one of the contracts to have a distinct name will allow the compiler to generate compilation artifacts for both contracts successfully.

template_details.issue_description:
Access control plays an important role in segregation of privileges in smart contracts and other applications. If this is misconfigured or not properly validated on sensitive functions, it may lead to loss of funds, tokens and in some cases compromise of the smart contract.

The contract ${contract_name} is importing an access control library ${library_name} but the function ${function_name} is missing the modifier ${modifier_name}.
template_details.issue_remediation: It is recommended to go through the contract and observe the functions that are lacking an access control modifier. If they contain sensitive administrative actions, it is advised to add a suitable modifier to the same

template_details.issue_description: The initialize function in the contract was found to be missing critical modifiers. This allows a malicious user to call the initialize function multiple times. There are no checks to see if the function has already been initialized. A malicious owner can abuse that by retroactively changing certain configurations.
template_details.issue_remediation: Consider adding the initializer or the reinitializer modifier to the initialize function or adding a check to see if the function has already been initialized. This will prevent the user from calling the function multiple times.

A malicious owner can abuse that by retroactively changing certain configurations.

template_details.issue_description:
Solidity functions should always use the Checks-Effects-Interactions pattern which states that the initial stage will contain only checks and validations which resides in the modifiers.
Due to this reason, modifiers should only implement checks and validations inside of it and should not make state changes and external calls.
The contract ${contract_name} was found to be violating this pattern and the modifier ${modifier_name} was making sensitive state changes and modifications.
template_details.issue_remediation: Only use modifiers for implementing checks and validations. Do not make external calls or state changing actions inside modifiers.

The contract was found to be violating this pattern and the modifier was making sensitive state changes and modifications.

template_details.issue_description: When using the nonReentrant modifier, it is crucial to place it before all other modifiers in a function. Placing it first ensures that all other modifiers are unable to bypass the reentrancy protection.
template_details.issue_remediation: By following the best practice of placing the nonReentrant modifier before all other modifiers, you can significantly reduce the risk of reentrancy-related vulnerabilities. This simple yet effective approach can help augment the security posture of your Solidity smart contracts.
template_details.static_issue_description: When using the nonReentrant modifier, it is crucial to place it before all other modifiers in a function. Placing it first ensures that all other modifiers are unable to bypass the reentrancy protection.

template_details.issue_description: The contract is found to lack proper validation for zero address inputs in critical functions, particularly where an 'address' input is expected, like during initialization or setting ownership. Failure to validate zero addresses can result in unwanted contract states, such as having critical roles or operations reference the zero address (0x0), which is universally considered an invalid and non-operational address within Ethereum, potentially leading to the loss of assets or control over the contract's functionality.
template_details.issue_remediation: To remediate the zero address vulnerability, it is essential to implement checks that ensure the 'address' inputs are not the zero address. This can be effectively done using a require statement (or similar error handling) to confirm that the provided address is not address(0). By integrating these checks, developers can prevent contracts from entering invalid states or executing critical operations with the zero address.

Failure to validate zero addresses can result in unwanted contract states, such as having critical roles or operations reference the zero address (0x0), which is universally considered an invalid and non-operational address within Ethereum, potentially leading to the loss of assets or control over the contract's functionality.

template_details.issue_description:
A common defensive programming technique that is useful in enforcing correct state transitions or validating operations is invariant-checking.
In particular, there is one apparent invariant that may be tempting to use but can in fact be manipulated by external users (regardless of the rules put in place in the smart contract). This is the current ether stored in the contract. (this.balance)
There are two ways in which malicious actors can (forcibly) send Ether to a contract without using a payable function or executing any code on the contract therefore compromising the contract logic depending on this.balance.
These are selfdestruct/suicide and pre-loading the contract with Ether.
template_details.issue_remediation:
This vulnerability typically arises from the misuse of this.balance contract logic. When possible, developers should avoid being dependent on exact values of the balance of the contract because it can be artificially manipulated.
If applying logic based on this.balance, ensure to account for unexpected balances.
If exact values of deposited Ether are required, a self-defined variable should be used that gets incremented in payable functions, to safely track the deposited Ether. This variable will not be influenced by the forced ether sent via a selfdestruct() call.

template_details.issue_description: The contract is found to lack a check for zero value transfers before executing the function. This oversight can lead to failures when interacting with certain ERC20 tokens, such as LEND, which revert transactions when a zero transfer is attempted. This can disrupt the flow of the contract and lead to unexpected behavior.
template_details.issue_name: LACK OF ZERO VALUE CHECK IN TOKEN TRANSFERS
template_details.issue_remediation: To remediate this issue, implement a check to ensure that the amount is greater than zero before calling the function. This can be done by adding a simple require statement, such as require(amount > 0, "Amount must be greater than zero");, before the transfer call.

template_details.issue_description:
The require Solidity function guarantees the validity of the condition(s) passed as a parameter that cannot be detected before execution. It checks inputs, contract state variables, and return values from calls to external contracts.


Using require instead of revert improves the overall readability of the contract code.


The construction if (condition) { revert(); } is equivalent to require(!condition);
template_details.issue_remediation: Depending on the contract's validation checks, it is recommended to use the require function to handle input validations.

template_details.issue_description: In public and external functions, improper use of revert can be exploited for Denial of Service (DoS) attacks. An attacker can intentionally trigger these 'revert' conditions, causing legitimate transactions to consistently fail. For example, if a function relies on specific conditions from user input or contract state, an attacker could manipulate these to continually force reverts, blocking the function's execution.
template_details.issue_name: REVERT STATEMENTS WITHIN EXTERNAL AND PUBLIC FUNCTIONS CAN BE USED TO PERFORM DOS ATTACKS
template_details.issue_remediation: To mitigate this issue, ensure that revert conditions are not solely dependent on user input or external state that can be manipulated. Implement checks and balances to handle such conditions gracefully, such as using a circuit breaker pattern or implementing rate limiting. Additionally, consider logging failed attempts and setting thresholds to identify and block potential attackers.
template_details.static_issue_description: In public and external functions, improper use of revert can be exploited for Denial of Service (DoS) attacks. An attacker can intentionally trigger these 'revert' conditions, causing legitimate transactions to consistently fail. For example, if a function relies on specific conditions from user input or contract state, an attacker could manipulate these to continually force reverts, blocking the function's execution.

template_details.issue_description:
Contracts often need access to time values to perform certain types of functionality. Values such as block.timestamp and block.number can be used to determine the current time or the time delta. However, they are not recommended for most use cases.


For block.number, as Ethereum block times are generally around 14 seconds, the delta between blocks can be predicted. The block times, on the other hand, do not remain constant and are subject to change for a number of reasons, e.g., fork reorganizations and the difficulty bomb.


Due to variable block times, block.number should not be relied on for precise calculations of time.
template_details.issue_name: BLOCK VALUES AS A PROXY FOR TIME
template_details.issue_remediation: It is recommended to use trusted external time sources, block numbers instead of timestamps, and/or utilizing multiple time sources to increase reliability. These practices can help mitigate risks of timestamp manipulation and inaccurate timing, increasing the reliability and security of the smart contract.
template_details.scwe_title: Block Values as a Proxy for Time

Due to variable block times, block.number should not be relied on for precise calculations of time.

template_details.issue_description: In Solidity, efficient use of gas is paramount to ensure cost-effective execution on the Ethereum blockchain. Gas can be optimized when obtaining contract balance by using selfbalance() rather than address(this).balance because it bypasses gas costs and refunds, which are not required for obtaining the contract's balance.
template_details.issue_remediation: To rectify this issue, developers are encouraged to replace instances of address(this).balance with selfbalance() wherever applicable. This optimization not only ensures streamlined gas operations but also contributes to substantial cost savings during contract execution.

template_details.issue_description:
The require() and revert() functions take an input string to show errors if the validation fails.
This strings inside these functions that are longer than 32 bytes require at least one additional MSTORE, along with additional overhead for computing memory offset, and other parameters.
template_details.issue_remediation: It is recommended to short the strings passed inside require() and revert() to fit under 32 bytes. This will decrease the gas usage at the time of deployment and at runtime when the validation condition is met.

template_details.issue_remediation: It is suggested to mark the constructors as payable to save some gas. Make sure it does not lead to any adverse effects in case an upgrade pattern is involved.

template_details.issue_description:
Combining multiple address/ID mappings into a single mapping using a struct enhances storage efficiency, simplifies code, and reduces gas costs, resulting in a more streamlined and cost-effective smart contract design.

It saves storage slot for the mapping and depending on the circumstances and sizes of types, it can avoid a Gsset (20000 gas) per mapping combined. Reads and subsequent writes can also be cheaper when a function requires both values and they fit in the same storage slot.
template_details.issue_remediation: It is suggested to modify the code so that multiple mappings using the address->id parameter are combined into a struct.

template_details.issue_description: Plus equals (+=) costs more gas than addition operator. The same thing happens with minus equals (-=). Therefore, x ${operator}y costs more gas than x = x ${parsed_operator} y.
template_details.issue_remediation:
Consider

  • addition operator over plus equals
  • subtraction operator over minus equals
  • division operator over divide equals
  • multiplication operator over multiply equals
template_details.static_issue_description: Plus equals (+=) costs more gas than addition operator. The same thing happens with minus equals (-=).

template_details.issue_description:
The contract ${contract_name} is using the state variable ${var_name} multiple times in the function ${func_name}.

SLOADs are expensive (100 gas after the 1st one) compared to MLOAD/MSTORE (3 gas each).
template_details.issue_remediation: Storage variables read multiple times inside a function should instead be cached in the memory the first time (costing 1 SLOAD) and then read from this cache to avoid multiple SLOADs.
template_details.static_issue_description:
The contract is using the state variable multiple times in the function.

SLOADs are expensive (100 gas after the 1st one) compared to MLOAD/MSTORE (3 gas each).

template_details.issue_description: If a function modifier such as onlyOwner is used, the function will revert if a normal user tries to pay the function. Marking the function as payable will lower the gas cost for legitimate callers because the compiler will not include checks for whether a payment was provided.
template_details.issue_remediation: In the above code, the onlyOwner modifier ensures that only the contract owner can execute the ${function_name}. If a normal user attempts to call this function, the transaction will automatically revert. By marking the ${function_name} as payable, we can optimize gas costs for legitimate callers since the compiler will skip the checks for payment.

template_details.issue_description:
The contract was found to be doing comparisons using inequalities inside the if statement.
When inside the if statements, non-strict inequalities (>=, <=) are usually cheaper than the strict equalities (>, <).
template_details.issue_remediation: It is recommended to go through the code logic, and, if possible, modify the strict inequalities with the non-strict ones to save ~3 gas as long as the logic of the code is not affected.

template_details.issue_description: The repeated usage of address(this) within the contract could result in increased gas costs due to multiple executions of the same computation, potentially impacting efficiency and overall transaction expenses.
template_details.issue_name: CACHE ADDRESS(THIS) WHEN USED MORE THAN ONCE
template_details.issue_remediation: Optimize gas usage by caching the value of address(this) and reusing it throughout the contract, reducing redundant computations and thereby enhancing efficiency.
template_details.static_issue_description: The repeated usage of address(this) within the contract could result in increased gas costs due to multiple executions of the same computation, potentially impacting efficiency and overall transaction expenses.

template_details.issue_description: The function is found to be allowing re-storing the value in the contract's state variable even when the old value is equal to the new value. This practice results in unnecessary gas consumption due to the Gsreset operation (2900 gas), which could be avoided. If the old value and the new value are the same, not updating the storage would avoid this cost and could instead incur a Gcoldsload (2100 gas) or a Gwarmaccess (100 gas), potentially saving gas.
template_details.issue_remediation: To optimize gas usage, add a check to compare the old value with the new value before updating the storage. Only perform the storage update if the new value is different from the old value. This approach will prevent unnecessary storage writes and reduce gas consumption.

template_details.issue_description: The contract is found to inefficiently reset integer variables to their default value of zero using manual assignment. In Solidity, manually setting a variable to its default value does not free up storage space, leading to unnecessary gas consumption. Instead, using the .delete keyword can achieve the same result while also freeing up storage space on the Ethereum blockchain, resulting in gas cost savings.
template_details.issue_name: DEFAULT INT VALUES ARE MANUALLY RESET
template_details.issue_remediation: To optimize gas usage, replace manual resets of integer variables with the .delete keyword. This not only sets the variable to its default value but also frees up storage space, leading to reduced gas costs.
template_details.static_issue_description: The contract is found to inefficiently reset integer variables to their default value of zero using manual assignment. In Solidity, manually setting a variable to its default value does not free up storage space, leading to unnecessary gas consumption. Instead, using the .delete keyword can achieve the same result while also freeing up storage space on the Ethereum blockchain, resulting in gas cost savings.

template_details.issue_description: The contract is found to contain a struct with multiple variables defined in it. When a struct is assigned in a single operation, Solidity may perform costly storage operations, which can be inefficient. This often results in increased gas costs due to multiple SLOAD and SSTORE operations happening at once
template_details.issue_name: ASSIGNING TO STRUCTS CAN BE MORE EFFICIENT
template_details.issue_remediation: Instead of assigning all struct elements at once, initialize the struct as empty and assign each element individually. This can help in reducing gas costs by minimizing potentially expensive storage operations in a single transaction.

template_details.issue_description:
Public constant variables cost more gas because the EVM automatically creates getter functions for them and adds entries to the method ID table. The values can be read from the source code instead.
The following variable is affected: ${variable_name}
template_details.issue_remediation: If reading the values for the constants are not necessary, consider changing the public visibility to private.
template_details.static_issue_description: Public constant variables cost more gas because the EVM automatically creates getter functions for them and adds entries to the method ID table. The values can be read from the source code instead.

template_details.issue_description: The contract is found to use multiple operands within a single if or else if statement, which can lead to unnecessary gas consumption due to the way the EVM evaluates compound boolean expressions. Each operand in a compound condition is evaluated even if the first condition fails, unless short-circuiting occurs, and the combined logic can result in more complex bytecode and higher gas usage compared to using nested if statements. This inefficiency is particularly relevant in functions that are called frequently or within loops.
template_details.issue_name: GAS INEFFICIENCY DUE TO MULTIPLE OPERANDS IN SINGLE IF/ELSEIF CONDITION
template_details.issue_remediation: To optimise gas usage, refactor compound conditional statements into nested if statements. This allows the EVM to short-circuit evaluation and avoid unnecessary computation, resulting in lower gas costs.

template_details.issue_description: The internal function ${func_name} was called only once throughout the contract. Internal functions cost more gas due to additional JUMP instructions and stack operations.
template_details.issue_remediation: Creating a function for a single call is not necessary if it can be in-lined. It is recommended to implement the logic using in-line codes to save gas.

template_details.issue_description: block.timestamp and block.number are by default added to event information. Adding them manually costs extra gas.
template_details.issue_remediation: block.timestamp and block.number do not need to be added manually. Consider removing them from the emitted events.

template_details.issue_description:
The contract was found to be using revert() statements. Since Solidity v0.8.4, custom errors have been introduced which are a better alternative to the revert.
This allows the developers to pass custom errors with dynamic data while reverting the transaction and also making the whole implementation a bit cheaper than using revert.
template_details.issue_remediation: It is recommended to replace all the instances of revert() statements with error() to save gas.

template_details.issue_description: The contract is found to use OpenZeppelin libraries for ownership and token standards, which, while robust and widely used, may not be the most gas-efficient choice. Solady provides equivalent modules that are specifically optimized for gas efficiency, which can lead to significant cost savings in transaction fees. Using Solady's versions of these libraries can help reduce the overall gas consumption of the contract, making it more efficient and cost-effective for users.
template_details.issue_remediation: To remediate this issue, replace the OpenZeppelin imports with their Solady equivalents. This involves changing the import paths to Solady's libraries, which are designed to be more gas-efficient. Ensure that the functionality provided by Solady matches the requirements of your contract, as there might be slight differences in implementation. Thoroughly test the contract after making these changes to ensure that all functionalities work as expected.

template_details.issue_description: The contract is using abi.encode() in the function ${function_name}. In abi.encode(), all elementary types are padded to 32 bytes and dynamic arrays include their length, whereas abi.encodePacked() will only use the minimal required memory to encode the data.
template_details.issue_name: ABI ENCODE IS LESS EFFICIENT THAN ABI ENCODEPACKED
template_details.issue_remediation: Unless explicitly needed , it is recommended to use abi.encodePacked() instead of abi.encode().
template_details.static_issue_description: The contract is using abi.encode() in the function. In abi.encode(), all elementary types are padded to 32 bytes and dynamic arrays include their length, whereas abi.encodePacked() will only use the minimal required memory to encode the data.

template_details.issue_description: Writing a storage variable from zero to a non-zero value costs 22,100 gas (20,000 for the write and 2,100 for cold access), making it one of the most expensive operations. This is why patterns like OpenZeppelin�s ReentrancyGuard use 1 and 2 instead of 0 and 1�to avoid the high cost of zero-to-non-zero writes. Non-zero to non-zero updates cost only 5,000 gas.
template_details.issue_remediation: To mitigate this gas inefficiency, consider initializing storage variables to non-zero values during contract deployment if possible. Alternatively, design contract logic to minimize the number of times storage variables are set from zero to non-zero values. This can be achieved by setting default non-zero values where applicable or by batching storage updates to reduce the frequency of costly initializations.

template_details.issue_description: Usage of smaller integer types such as uint8, uint16, int8, or int16 in arithmetic operations incur additional gas costs compared to the default uint and int types, which are typically uint256 and int256 respectively.
template_details.issue_remediation: Replace occurrences of smaller integer types (uint8, uint16, int8, int16) with the default integer types (uint or int). This can be achieved by simply using uint or int, which are automatically mapped to uint256 and int256 respectively in Solidity version 0.8.0 and above.
template_details.static_issue_description: Usage of smaller integer types such as uint8, uint16, int8, or int16 in arithmetic operations incur additional gas costs compared to the default uint and int types, which are typically uint256 and int256 respectively.

Solidity is a Gas-constrained language. Having unused code or import statements incurs extra gas usage when deploying the contract.
The contract was found to be importing the file ${flagged_import} which is not used anywhere in the code.
template_details.issue_remediation: It is recommended to remove the import statement if it�s not supposed to be used.

description_details.exploit_scenario: 1) Contract is deployed normally with constructor (owner set to a legitimate address). 2) Before the legitimate owner calls initialize() (or even if they never intend to), an attacker calls initialize(attackerEOA, _token). 3) The initializer modifier sets initialized = true and _transferOwnership(attackerEOA) transfers ownership to the attacker. 4) Attacker now controls setExecutor, setMaxRescueAmount, pause/unpause and can censor or reshape execution behavior.
description_details.impact: An attacker can seize full owner privileges on a non-proxy deployment. With ownership, the attacker can pause/unpause the contract, set or unset executors, change maxRescueAmount, and effectively control rescue execution policy for all users�disrupting operations or censoring rescues. This is a complete administrative takeover.
description_details.remediation: Ensure the contract is not vulnerable to post-constructor initialization. Options: (a) Set initialized = true in the constructor to permanently disable initialize() on constructor-based deployments; (b) Remove initialize() entirely if the contract is not intended to be used behind a proxy; or (c) Convert fully to an upgradeable pattern (use OpenZeppelin Initializable with upgradeable base contracts) and deploy only via proxy, with initialize() called atomically by the deployer. Also avoid taking an arbitrary _owner parameter; if using initialize(), consider setting the owner to msg.sender to avoid third-party hijack via parameter injection.
description_details.technical_description: The contract supports two deployment modes: a constructor-based deployment (Ownable(owner_)) and a separate initialize() function gated only by the local initializer modifier. In constructor deployments, the initialized flag remains false because it is only set inside the initializer modifier, not in the constructor. Consequently, after a regular deployment using the constructor (which already sets the owner), any external caller can still invoke initialize() exactly once and arbitrarily reassign ownership via _transferOwnership(_owner). There is no onlyOwner protection on initialize(), and it accepts an arbitrary _owner parameter, enabling hostile reconfiguration of ownership after deployment.
description_details.title: Unprotected initializer allows post-deployment ownership hijack

metric_wise_aggregated_findings.issue_description:
Description:
The contract supports two deployment modes: a constructor-based deployment (Ownable(owner_)) and a separate initialize() function gated only by the local initializer modifier. In constructor deployments, the initialized flag remains false because it is only set inside the initializer modifier, not in the constructor. Consequently, after a regular deployment using the constructor (which already sets the owner), any external caller can still invoke initialize() exactly once and arbitrarily reassign ownership via _transferOwnership(_owner). There is no onlyOwner protection on initialize(), and it accepts an arbitrary _owner parameter, enabling hostile reconfiguration of ownership after deployment.

Impact:
An attacker can seize full owner privileges on a non-proxy deployment. With ownership, the attacker can pause/unpause the contract, set or unset executors, change maxRescueAmount, and effectively control rescue execution policy for all users�disrupting operations or censoring rescues. This is a complete administrative takeover.

Exploit Scenario:
1) Contract is deployed normally with constructor (owner set to a legitimate address). 2) Before the legitimate owner calls initialize() (or even if they never intend to), an attacker calls initialize(attackerEOA, _token). 3) The initializer modifier sets initialized = true and _transferOwnership(attackerEOA) transfers ownership to the attacker. 4) Attacker now controls setExecutor, setMaxRescueAmount, pause/unpause and can censor or reshape execution behavior.
metric_wise_aggregated_findings.issue_remediation: Ensure the contract is not vulnerable to post-constructor initialization. Options: (a) Set initialized = true in the constructor to permanently disable initialize() on constructor-based deployments; (b) Remove initialize() entirely if the contract is not intended to be used behind a proxy; or (c) Convert fully to an upgradeable pattern (use OpenZeppelin Initializable with upgradeable base contracts) and deploy only via proxy, with initialize() called atomically by the deployer. Also avoid taking an arbitrary _owner parameter; if using initialize(), consider setting the owner to msg.sender to avoid third-party hijack via parameter injection.

description_details.exploit_scenario: Owner funds 1,000 SNRG, but SNRG charges a 2% transfer fee. The contract receives 980 tokens, yet rewardReserve is set to 1,000. Stakers are admitted until promisedRewards reaches 1,000. When rewards must be paid, the contract lacks 20 tokens and withdrawals revert.
description_details.impact: The contract can promise more rewards than it actually holds, causing later withdrawals to revert due to insufficient token balance. Users� principal and rewards may become temporarily or permanently stuck if actual reserves are lower than recorded.
description_details.remediation: Compute actual received using balance-before/balance-after when funding. Example: read contract balance, perform safeTransferFrom, compute actualReceived = balanceAfter - balanceBefore, and set rewardReserve += actualReceived. Remove fragile balance pre-checks relying on balanceOf(TREASURY).
description_details.technical_description: fundContract sets rewardReserve = amount based on the requested transfer amount rather than the actual tokens received by the contract. For ERC20s with transfer fees, blacklists, or non-standard behavior, the contract may receive less than amount, but rewardReserve is still increased by amount. This creates a mismatch between on-chain token balance and internal reserve accounting used to admit new stakes and to assess solvency.
description_details.title: Reward reserve accounting overestimates reserves when funding with fee-on-transfer/deflationary tokens

metric_wise_aggregated_findings.issue_description:
Description:
fundContract sets rewardReserve = amount based on the requested transfer amount rather than the actual tokens received by the contract. For ERC20s with transfer fees, blacklists, or non-standard behavior, the contract may receive less than amount, but rewardReserve is still increased by amount. This creates a mismatch between on-chain token balance and internal reserve accounting used to admit new stakes and to assess solvency.

Impact:
The contract can promise more rewards than it actually holds, causing later withdrawals to revert due to insufficient token balance. Users� principal and rewards may become temporarily or permanently stuck if actual reserves are lower than recorded.

Exploit Scenario:
Owner funds 1,000 SNRG, but SNRG charges a 2% transfer fee. The contract receives 980 tokens, yet rewardReserve is set to 1,000. Stakers are admitted until promisedRewards reaches 1,000. When rewards must be paid, the contract lacks 20 tokens and withdrawals revert.
metric_wise_aggregated_findings.issue_remediation: Compute actual received using balance-before/balance-after when funding. Example: read contract balance, perform safeTransferFrom, compute actualReceived = balanceAfter - balanceBefore, and set rewardReserve += actualReceived. Remove fragile balance pre-checks relying on balanceOf(TREASURY).

description_details.exploit_scenario: Owner calls topUpReserves(10,000) on a token with a 5% tax. Only 9,500 tokens arrive, but rewardReserve increases by 10,000. Stakers are allowed until promisedRewards reaches the inflated reserve; later reward payouts can fail.
description_details.impact: Same as in funding: the contract�s promisedRewards can exceed the real token reserves, leading to reverted withdrawals and stuck funds.
description_details.remediation: Mirror the stake() pattern: measure actual received via balance delta and add that to rewardReserve instead of the input amount.
description_details.technical_description: topUpReserves increases rewardReserve by the requested amount without verifying how many tokens were actually received. With transfer-taxed tokens, fewer tokens can arrive than amount, but rewardReserve is still incremented by amount, inflating reserves.
description_details.title: Reserve top-up also overestimates reserves if token takes transfer fees

template_details.issue_name: TOKEN DECIMALS MISMATCH IN SEIZE REPAY

description_details.exploit_scenario: Owner mistakenly calls topUpReserves(5,000) before initial funding. rewardReserve becomes 5,000. Later, owner calls fundContract(2,000), which sets rewardReserve = 2,000, overwriting the earlier 5,000 and making the system appear underfunded by 3,000 in its bookkeeping.
description_details.impact: Mis-accounting reduces available reserves in bookkeeping, potentially blocking valid stakes (overly conservative) or confusing operators. While it does not directly lose tokens, it can disrupt system operation and monitoring.
description_details.remediation: Either: (a) set isFunded = true in the first successful topUpReserves and prevent fundContract from resetting rewardReserve; or (b) make topUpReserves require isFunded == true; or (c) have fundContract add to rewardReserve instead of overwriting it (rewardReserve += actualReceived).
description_details.technical_description: topUpReserves can be called before the contract is initially funded (isFunded == false). Later, fundContract sets isFunded = true and assigns rewardReserve = amount, overwriting any prior top-ups already added to rewardReserve. This silently discards earlier top-up accounting and produces an incorrect reserve value.
description_details.title: Pre-funding top-ups are overwritten by the initial fundContract call, corrupting reserve accounting

metric_wise_aggregated_findings.issue_description:

topUpReserves can be called before the contract is initially funded (isFunded == false). Later, fundContract sets isFunded = true and assigns rewardReserve = amount, overwriting any prior top-ups already added to rewardReserve. This silently discards earlier top-up accounting and produces an incorrect reserve value.

Impact:
Mis-accounting reduces available reserves in bookkeeping, potentially blocking valid stakes (overly conservative) or confusing operators. While it does not directly lose tokens, it can disrupt system operation and monitoring.

Exploit Scenario:
Owner mistakenly calls topUpReserves(5,000) before initial funding. rewardReserve becomes 5,000. Later, owner calls fundContract(2,000), which sets rewardReserve = 2,000, overwriting the earlier 5,000 and making the system appear underfunded by 3,000 in its bookkeeping.
metric_wise_aggregated_findings.issue_remediation: Either: (a) set isFunded = true in the first successful topUpReserves and prevent fundContract from resetting rewardReserve; or (b) make topUpReserves require isFunded == true; or (c) have fundContract add to rewardReserve instead of overwriting it (rewardReserve += actualReceived).

description_details.exploit_scenario: User stakes 1,000 tokens; later, withdraw attempts to transfer 1,050 (principal + reward). If SNRG takes 2% on transfer, the user only receives 1,029 while the contract believes it paid 1,050. The discrepancy silently harms users.
description_details.impact: Users may be underpaid on withdrawal when the token charges fees on transfer. The system�s accounting assumes full amounts were delivered, but the user actually receives less, causing economic loss to users and inconsistency between expectations and actual receipt.
description_details.remediation: Either explicitly restrict SNRG to standard non-deflationary ERC20s via documentation and enforcement (e.g., whitelisting known token, adding a one-time immutable check), or implement balance-delta based transfers and adjust internal accounting accordingly. If supporting taxed tokens, rework logic to ensure the user receives the intended net amounts and fees are handled explicitly. Additionally, document token compatibility assumptions.
description_details.technical_description: withdraw, withdrawEarly, and emergencyWithdraw transfer fixed amounts with safeTransfer but do not verify the user actually receives s.amount (+/- fees/reward). If SNRG deducts a transfer fee on outbound transfers, users will receive less than the recorded owed amounts while the contract decreases rewardReserve (for withdraw) or sends a fee to TREASURY based on pre-fee amounts.
description_details.title: Outgoing payout transfers do not account for transfer-taxed tokens, underpaying users relative to recorded amounts

metric_wise_aggregated_findings.issue_description:

If SNRG deducts a transfer fee on outbound transfers, users will receive less than the recorded owed amounts while the contract decreases rewardReserve (for withdraw) or sends a fee to TREASURY based on pre-fee amounts.

Impact:

Exploit Scenario:

If supporting taxed tokens, rework logic to ensure the user receives the intended net amounts and fees are handled explicitly. Additionally, document token compatibility assumptions.

description_details.exploit_scenario: After funding with a taxed token, rewardReserve is overstated by 2%. isSolvent returns true, but when paying rewards, transfers revert due to insufficient balance.
description_details.impact: Operators and users can be misled into believing the system is solvent, risking failed withdrawals later.
description_details.remediation: Base reserve accounting on actual received tokens during funding/top-ups. Optionally, enhance solvency views to compare on-chain balances against internal counters and surface discrepancies.
description_details.technical_description: isSolvent reports rewardReserve >= promisedRewards but does not validate that rewardReserve corresponds to real, spendable tokens held by the contract. Due to the funding/top-up overcounting issues, the function can return true while the actual contract balance is insufficient to cover promised rewards.
description_details.title: Solvency check relies on internal counters that can diverge from reality

metric_wise_aggregated_findings.issue_description:
Description:
isSolvent reports rewardReserve >= promisedRewards but does not validate that rewardReserve corresponds to real, spendable tokens held by the contract. Due to the funding/top-up overcounting issues, the function can return true while the actual contract balance is insufficient to cover promised rewards.

Impact:
Operators and users can be misled into believing the system is solvent, risking failed withdrawals later.

Exploit Scenario:
After funding with a taxed token, rewardReserve is overstated by 2%. isSolvent returns true, but when paying rewards, transfers revert due to insufficient balance.
metric_wise_aggregated_findings.issue_remediation: Base reserve accounting on actual received tokens during funding/top-ups. Optionally, enhance solvency views to compare on-chain balances against internal counters and surface discrepancies.

template_details.issue_name: SOLVENCY CHECK RELIES ON INTERNAL COUNTERS THAT CAN DIVERGE FROM REALITY

description_details.exploit_scenario: Assume SNRG�s burnFrom burns amount but also confiscates an additional 10% fee to a feeCollector. A user calls burnForReceipt with amount = 1,000. The token burns 1,000 and transfers 100 to feeCollector. The user�s balance drops by 1,100, so burnedActual = 1,100 and the contract credits 1,100 to burned[msg.sender]. The user receives credit exceeding the actual burn by 100, diluting others in the migration distribution based on burned mapping.
description_details.impact: Users can be credited for more than the number of tokens actually burned, distorting the migration accounting and diluting other users in the new token distribution. If the excess balance reduction is not a true burn (e.g., sent as a fee to a third party), totalBurned will overstate actual old-token burn, enabling over-allocation of the new token to such users.
description_details.remediation: Credit the lesser of (amount, burnedActual), or better, derive credit from an on-chain verifiable measure of destruction such as totalSupply delta if IBurnable guarantees totalSupply decreases exactly by the burned amount. Alternatively, require IBurnable.burnFrom to return the exact burned amount and trust only that return value, or restrict SNRG to a known, audited implementation whose burn semantics are proven and immutable.
description_details.technical_description: burnForReceipt computes burnedActual as balanceBefore - balanceAfter and only enforces burnedActual >= amount. If IBurnable.burnFrom(msg.sender, amount) reduces the caller�s balance by more than amount due to non-standard behavior (e.g., fee-on-burn, confiscation, or a coupled transfer), the contract credits burned[msg.sender] and totalBurned with the larger burnedActual. This credits non-burn balance decreases as if they were burns, diverging from the intended invariant that receipts represent actual tokens destroyed.
description_details.title: Over-crediting receipts when SNRG.burnFrom reduces balance by more than the requested amount

This credits non-burn balance decreases as if they were burns, diverging from the intended invariant that receipts represent actual tokens destroyed.

Impact:
Users can be credited for more than the number of tokens actually burned, distorting the migration accounting and diluting other users in the new token distribution. The user receives credit exceeding the actual burn by 100, diluting others in the migration distribution based on burned mapping.
metric_wise_aggregated_findings.issue_remediation: Credit the lesser of (amount, burnedActual), or better, derive credit from an on-chain verifiable measure of destruction such as totalSupply delta if IBurnable guarantees totalSupply decreases exactly by the burned amount. Alternatively, require IBurnable.burnFrom to return the exact burned amount and trust only that return value, or restrict SNRG to a known, audited implementation whose burn semantics are proven and immutable.

description_details.exploit_scenario: Owner proposes a root that omits certain addresses. After the 48-hour delay, the owner calls finalize and sets the malicious root as merkleRoot. Affected users cannot claim in the downstream migration contract reading this root, despite having legitimately burned tokens on-chain.

findings.ai_tagged_reason: The contract explicitly adopts a governance/trust model with a timelock: proposeRoot is onlyOwner, RootProposed is emitted, and finalize requires FINALIZE_DELAY and a non-zero totalBurned. The comments indicate the community is expected to verify the root off-chain during the delay. Given the absence of on-chain Merkle validation, this is an intentional design choice rather than a technical vulnerability in the contract�s scope.

description_details.impact: A malicious or careless owner can finalize a root that omits users or misallocates amounts. Late burns occurring after proposeRoot but before finalize can be excluded, depriving users of expected allocations in downstream claim logic relying on merkleRoot.
description_details.remediation: Introduce an on-chain snapshot at proposal time (e.g., totalBurnedSnapshot = totalBurned and a monotonically increasing proposalId), then require no additional burns (or require the contract to be paused) until finalize so the off-chain computed root matches the snapshot. Alternatively, enforce an invariant at finalize that a supplied commitment (e.g., totalBurned encoded in the root metadata) matches the on-chain snapshot, and require proposeRoot only when paused.
description_details.technical_description: finalize only checks that a proposedRoot exists, the FINALIZE_DELAY has elapsed, and totalBurned > 0. There is no on-chain link tying merkleRoot�s contents or sum to the burned mapping or totalBurned. Moreover, burns are allowed to continue after proposeRoot, so a root computed off-chain at proposedAt can become stale before finalize executes.

template_details.issue_name: OWNER CAN FINALIZE AN ARBITRARY OR STALE MERKLE ROOT; NO ON-CHAIN LINKAGE BETWEEN MERKLEROOT AND BURNED ACCOUNTING

description_details.exploit_scenario: An external migration claim contract validates proofs against SNRGSwap.merkleRoot. While claims are ongoing, the owner calls reopenFinalization, which sets merkleRoot to 0 immediately. All in-flight and subsequent claims fail until a new root is proposed and finalized after the 48-hour delay.

findings.ai_tagged_reason: This risk depends on an external contract reading merkleRoot live from SNRGSwap for claims. The provided codebase does not include such a claim contract; reopening is implemented with a clear event trail and a new timelock for the replacement root. If integrators batch updates or reference a separate claim contract state, the immediate clearing may be harmless. Thus, this is likely an integration consideration rather than an exploitable on-chain bug in SNRGSwap.

description_details.impact: Claims depending on merkleRoot can fail or be halted for the entire FINALIZE_DELAY window after reopening, impacting availability and user experience. Attack surface exists if the owner reopens frequently or maliciously.
description_details.remediation: Adopt a two-phase switch: queue the replacement root and keep the existing merkleRoot active until the new root�s timelock elapses, then atomically swap roots. Alternatively, require the contract to be paused and/or enforce a short grace period before clearing merkleRoot so integrators can halt new claims cleanly.
description_details.technical_description: reopenFinalization clears merkleRoot (sets it to 0) and flips finalized to false before queuing the replacement root. There is no grace period for the clearing step. If external claim logic references this contract�s merkleRoot for live verification, clearing it immediately can break ongoing claims until the new root becomes final after the timelock.
description_details.title: Immediate clearing of merkleRoot during reopenFinalization can break integrators and temporarily DoS claims

description_details.exploit_scenario: After proposeRoot at time T, an attacker or regular user calls burnForReceipt with a large amount at T+1h. The owner does not cancel and repropose, and after the delay finalizes the original root. The late burn is not reflected in the finalized root, excluding that user from claims.

findings.ai_tagged_reason: The design appears intentional: proposeRoot during an active burn window with a timelock so off-chain verification can occur, and the owner can cancel and repropose if additional burns occur. Root staleness is a governance/operational risk to be managed by the owner and community monitoring, not a code flaw exploited by attackers within SNRGSwap.

description_details.impact: Late burners may be excluded from the finalized root, causing misalignment between on-chain burned accounting and downstream distribution, unless the owner cancels and reproposes.
description_details.remediation: On proposeRoot: pause the contract, snapshot totalBurned, and disallow further burns until finalize or cancel. On finalize: verify that totalBurned equals the snapshot taken at proposal. Alternatively, automatically cancel the pending root if totalBurned changes after proposal and emit an event instructing off-chain systems to recompute.
description_details.technical_description: proposeRoot does not pause the contract or snapshot totalBurned. Users can continue calling burnForReceipt during the FINALIZE_DELAY window. finalize does not verify that totalBurned at finalize equals totalBurned at propose time. Thus, a root constructed off-chain at proposal time can become stale by finalize and still be accepted.
description_details.title: Finalization can proceed on stale accounting because burns remain allowed after proposeRoot

template_details.issue_name: FINALIZATION CAN PROCEED ON STALE ACCOUNTING BECAUSE BURNS REMAIN ALLOWED AFTER PROPOSEROOT

description_details.exploit_scenario: An IBurnable implementation�s burnFrom internally performs a transfer to a fee collector rather than reducing total supply, lowering the user�s balance but not burning tokens. SNRGSwap credits the user with the full balance decrease, overstating the actual destruction of old tokens and skewing migration accounting.

findings.ai_tagged_reason: The snippet omits IBurnable, but in a full repository IBurnable is likely defined or imported. The reliance on IBurnable is a compile-time/interface matter, not a runtime exploit. Additionally, burnForReceipt defends against under-burn by verifying a post-call balance decrease. Therefore, while integration mistakes are possible, this finding is likely a documentation/build artifact in the provided excerpt.

description_details.impact: Configuration or integration mistakes can lead to reverted burns, unexpected crediting, or reliance on effects that are not true burns. While not a direct on-chain exploit of SNRGSwap, it increases the risk of mis-accounting and availability issues.
description_details.remediation: Define and import the exact IBurnable interface used (e.g., a trusted ERC20Burnable-like interface) and document or enforce semantics. Consider validating the SNRG implementation at deployment, or reading totalSupply deltas if the burn semantics guarantee total supply reduction.
description_details.technical_description: The contract references IBurnable but the interface is not defined in this file. The code assumes IBurnable implements balanceOf and burnFrom with standard ERC20 semantics and revert behavior. If the actual token deviates (e.g., non-reverting on failure, extra side effects such as fee/confiscation, or rebase), burnForReceipt�s accounting may behave unexpectedly.

template_details.issue_name: UNDECLARED IBURNABLE INTERFACE AND RELIANCE ON EXTERNAL, NON-STANDARD TOKEN BEHAVIOR

description_details.exploit_scenario: An attacker transfers a large SNRG amount directly to the staking contract (toEndpoint path). If the staking contract calculates share price based on token.balanceOf(address(this)) without accounting for external donations, the attacker can manipulate the share price and then deposit/withdraw at a favorable rate, extracting value from honest users.
description_details.impact: Potential donation/griefing vectors against staking/swap contracts that do not defend against direct token transfers. Effects include mispriced shares, broken deposit/withdraw math, or dust buildup that cannot be claimed. While the vulnerability�s exploitability depends on endpoint code, the token explicitly enables such transfers.
description_details.remediation: If maintaining permissive toEndpoint behavior, ensure endpoint contracts are immune to donation attacks (e.g., use internal accounting that only updates on controlled deposit/withdraw functions and is independent of raw balance changes). Alternatively, constrain toEndpoint for staking/swap (e.g., only allow transfers originating from approved routers) or add a circuit-breaker that endpoints can query to reject unsolicited transfers.
description_details.technical_description: _update() allows transfers to endpoints from any address via the toEndpoint check ((to == staking) || (to == swap) || (to == presale)). This permits unsolicited token transfers to staking and swap addresses. If these endpoint contracts account using raw token balances (e.g., totalAssets = token.balanceOf(address(this))) without handling direct-donation scenarios, an attacker can skew pool accounting or share pricing via donations. This issue depends on external endpoint implementations but originates from the token�s permissive toEndpoint rule.
description_details.title: Unsolicited token donations to staking/swap endpoints may enable accounting manipulation in naive integrations

description_details.exploit_scenario: - Implementation is deployed with TOKEN = TokenA via constructor. - A proxy is deployed intended to use TOKEN = TokenB and calls initialize(owner, TokenB). - Because TOKEN is immutable, initialize() cannot update it; executeRescue() will continue interacting with TokenA. All allowance/balance checks and transferFrom are against TokenA, making rescues for TokenB impossible and likely reverting.
description_details.impact: Rescue operations can be permanently disabled (DoS) or misdirected to an unintended token address in proxy deployments. Users may not be able to execute rescues at all if TOKEN is wrong or zero; or rescues will affect a different token than intended, causing operational or financial damage.
description_details.remediation: Do not use immutable for TOKEN if proxy/factory initialization is required. Replace TOKEN with a storage variable and set it inside initialize(), or remove initialize() and only support constructor deployments. If immutability is desired, deploy separate implementations per token and avoid initialize(_token) entirely to prevent confusion; also remove the unused _token parameter from initialize() to eliminate misconfiguration risk.
description_details.technical_description: TOKEN is declared immutable and assigned in the constructor. The initialize(address _owner, address _token) function accepts _token but does not assign it to any storage�immutable variables cannot be set in an initializer. In a proxy setup, the implementation�s constructor does not run for the proxy, so the proxy will inherit the immutable value embedded at implementation deployment time (or an unintended value). All token interactions in executeRescue() rely on TOKEN (balanceOf, allowance, transferFrom). If TOKEN does not match the intended asset for the proxy instance, token reads/writes will target the wrong address and likely revert (e.g., calling ERC20 methods on address(0) returns insufficient data and reverts) or operate on the wrong token.
description_details.title: Immutable TOKEN cannot be configured via initialize; ignored parameter causes proxy misconfiguration/DoS

description_details.exploit_scenario: 1) User calls initiateRescue() setting lastRescueTime[user] = now. 2) User calls cancelRescue() which resets lastRescueTime[user] = 0. 3) User immediately calls initiateRescue() again; the cooldown check passes because 0 + RESCUE_COOLDOWN is in the past, allowing cooldown bypass. This can be repeated indefinitely.
description_details.impact: Users can repeatedly initiate rescues without respecting the intended cooldown period, undermining system rate limits and potentially causing operational load, spam, or unexpected execution cadence. This may also weaken any security assumptions that rely on enforced spacing between rescue initiations.
description_details.remediation: Do not reset lastRescueTime on cancel. Either: (a) leave lastRescueTime unchanged when canceling, thereby preserving the initiation timestamp for cooldown enforcement; or (b) record the last initiation time separately and always enforce the cooldown based on the most recent initiation, regardless of cancelation. If desired, introduce a separate lastExecuteTime or lastFinalizeTime for other rate-limiting semantics.
description_details.technical_description: initiateRescue() enforces a 90-day RESCUE_COOLDOWN by checking block.timestamp < lastRescueTime[msg.sender] + RESCUE_COOLDOWN. However, cancelRescue() sets lastRescueTime[msg.sender] = 0, effectively clearing the timestamp used for the cooldown calculation. As a result, the user can cancel a rescue and immediately call initiateRescue() again, bypassing the intended cooldown throttle.
description_details.title: Rescue cooldown bypass via cancelRescue() resetting lastRescueTime

description_details.exploit_scenario: The registry is configured to use a token that reverts or returns no data on transferFrom. executeRescue() expects a bool return and either decodes empty data (revert) or receives a false value (revert via TransferFailed), making rescues impossible.
description_details.impact: If TOKEN is a non-standard ERC20 that does not strictly return a boolean, executeRescue() may revert or behave unexpectedly, preventing rescues. This is an integration/compatibility DoS risk.
description_details.remediation: Use SafeERC20.safeTransferFrom(IERC20(TOKEN), ...) to handle both standard and non-standard ERC20 behaviors. If the system intentionally targets a strict IRestrictedToken that guarantees bool returns, document and enforce this constraint at configuration time and remove the unused SafeERC20 import to avoid confusion.
description_details.technical_description: executeRescue() invokes IRestrictedToken(TOKEN).transferFrom(victim, p.recovery, amount) and expects a boolean return value. Many ERC20 tokens are non-standard: some return no value (revert on failure) or have different behaviors. Relying on a bool return may cause reverts or false negatives with such tokens. Although SafeERC20 is imported, it is not used here to normalize transfer semantics.
description_details.title: Strict bool-return ERC20 interface in transferFrom can break compatibility and cause DoS

description_details.exploit_scenario: Multiple users exit early and forfeit rewards, decreasing promisedRewards but leaving rewardReserve unchanged. The difference (available rewards) grows but cannot be reclaimed or repurposed by the treasury due to the absence of a withdrawal/recovery function.
description_details.impact: Tokens can remain permanently locked in the contract, reducing treasury flexibility and operational control. Over time, unavailable funds can accumulate.
description_details.remediation: Add controlled functions for the owner to: (1) withdraw excess rewards up to availableRewards = rewardReserve - promisedRewards, and (2) recover arbitrary ERC20s sent by mistake. Gate with onlyOwner, nonReentrant, and events. Consider pausable checks as appropriate.
description_details.technical_description: The contract can accumulate tokens beyond promisedRewards (e.g., from early/emergency withdrawals where rewards are forfeited, or accidental token transfers). There is no owner function to withdraw the uncommitted portion of rewards (rewardReserve - promisedRewards) or to recover non-SNRG tokens mistakenly sent to the contract.
description_details.title: No mechanism to withdraw excess/unpromised reserves or recover stuck tokens

description_details.exploit_scenario: 1) A user mistakenly transfers SNRG directly to the presale address. 2) Later, the presale contract (or EOA if presale is an EOA) attempts to send the tokens back to the user. 3) The transfer reverts in _update() because fromEndpoint excludes presale and the receiver is not an endpoint, making none of the allowed conditions true. 4) The tokens remain stuck in presale unless a rescue executor intervenes.
description_details.impact: Users who send tokens directly to the presale address may cause those tokens to be stuck (unable to be transferred back to a normal address) unless an authorized rescue is executed or the tokens are routed through another endpoint that is permitted to send out. This can lead to permanent user fund loss and operational friction.
description_details.remediation: Consider either (a) disallowing inbound transfers to presale by removing it from toEndpoint, or (b) allowing presale -> any transfers by including presale in fromEndpoint, or (c) adding a dedicated, tightly scoped allowance (e.g., allow presale to transfer to non-endpoint addresses under specific conditions). At minimum, clearly document that sending tokens to presale directly will render them non-transferable to regular addresses without rescue.
description_details.technical_description: In _update(), transfers are allowed if any of the following holds: (1) from == TREASURY and to is an endpoint, (2) from is an endpoint (staking or swap only), (3) to is an endpoint (staking, swap, or presale), (4) msg.sender == presale and from == TREASURY, or (5) rescueMove is true. Notably, toEndpoint includes the presale address, but fromEndpoint explicitly excludes presale. As a result, tokens can be transferred to presale by any address, but presale cannot directly send tokens to arbitrary non-endpoint addresses. This creates an asymmetric flow for presale: presale -> non-endpoint is disallowed by design and will revert.
description_details.title: Funds sent to presale can become unrecoverable due to asymmetric endpoint rules

As a result, tokens can be transferred to presale by any address, but presale cannot directly send tokens to arbitrary non-endpoint addresses.
